awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Handheld graphene-based sensors for rapid detection of Salmonella species in food processing facilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is faster and accurate detection of Salmonella species in food processing plants. Salmonella bacteria are the most frequently reported cause of foodborne illness. Food contamination in processing facilities can lead to serious public health problems as well as costly recalls of millions of food units. Rapid and accurate sensing technology is currently lacking for definitive detection of Salmonella in food-processing plants, which delays initiation of appropriate control measures and increases the likelihood of spreading contamination and foodborne illnesses to consumers. This technology will enable more frequent testing throughout the entire manufacturing process at reduced costs. It is fully expected that this technology could be applied to the detection of other pathogens.

The proposed project will create and test a rapid (20 minutes), hand-held, sensitive (1 bacteria cell per milliliter) platform to enable food-processing facilities to detect Salmonella on site. The innovation of this technology lies in the ability to avoid bacterial enrichment (22 to 48 hours to allow bacteria to grow), while still sensitively and selectively detecting Salmonella species. The device uses a testing cartridge to bring bacteria directly to a detection surface, which consists of graphene printed or scribed on a test-strip and subsequently functionalized with Salmonella-specific antibodies. Unique laser processing induces a 3D-structured surface at the nanoscale level in graphene that becomes highly conductive for biosensing and for antibody attachment, which are desirable properties for enabling low detection limits and increasing test sensitivity. These technologies can be combined into a portable platform to make a user-friendly handheld biosensor and displaying quantitative counts of bacteria. The integrated platform (test strip and cartridge) will be designed to interface with existing portable electrical readers in much the same fashion that diabetics monitor blood glucose levels at home with a blood test strip that connects to a portable reader with a digital display.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Food contamination in processing facilities can lead to serious public health problems as well as costly recalls of millions of food units. The ability to produce pathogen-free food is dependent on current intervention and testing methods to determine whether food is considered safe. The detection process is time-consuming as it requires amplifying the bacteria to increase bacteria numbers since the current testing methods lack sensitivity (~100 colony forming units per milliliter, CFU/mL, limit of detection) and cannot detect lower levels of pathogens (1-5 CFU/mL) in complex samples. The objective of this Phase I proof of concept project was to establish technical feasibility of our proprietary graphene-based sensing platform for food safety testing. The project focused on the development of a sensor system for rapid foodborne pathogen detection (i.e., Salmonella) in poultry processing facility. Our device uses a testing cartridge to bring bacteria directly to the sensor detection surface, which consists of a graphene electrode on a substrate (i.e., polymer) functionalized with Salmonella-specific antibodies. Unique laser processing was used with different power settings to make the graphene highly conductive for sensing or to change the graphene surface from one that attracts water (hydrophilic) to one that repels liquid (hydrophobic), properties that are desirable for enabling high test sensitivity. These technologies can be combined into a portable platform to make a user-friendly, hand-held biosensor for displaying quantitative counts of bacteria. The integrated platform is designed to interface with existing portable electrochemical potentiostat devices. An electrochemical signal is generated after foodborne pathogens attach to the biosensor and the signal is monitored with a portable electrical reader in much the same fashion that diabetics monitor their blood glucose levels at home. This Phase I research explored three objectives to determine the technical and commercial feasibility of the proposed technology: Objective 1: Fabricate and biofunctionalize graphene-based biosensor for Salmonella detection. Objective 2: Test biosensor for Salmonella detection and integrate testing cartridge with Salmonella biosensor. Objective 3: Validate the integrated biosensor and testing cartridge in real environmental samples.

 

During the performance of this project, we worked on establishing technical feasibility of our proprietary graphene-based platform for food safety testing by developing and improving methods to fabricate graphene-based electrodes that are low-cost / high-yield for electrochemical monitoring of foodborne pathogens. We tested a variety of anti-Salmonella antibodies for selectivity, various methods for sensor biofunctionalization with antibodies, and blocking agents to prevent non-specific binding. The efficiency of the sensor was performed by testing the selectivity with Escherichia coli as an interferent bacterium and in a real food sample, chicken broth. Furthermore, we created simple methods for testing multiple sensors to accelerate our ability to perform experiments and later to be able to perform simultaneous detection of multiple foodborne pathogens that could be monitored from one swab sample. Additionally, we developed a simple test kit cartridge consisting of a sensor-chip (containing three electrodes) integrated into a testing tube (25-mL sample capacity) that can be used to collect swab samples and detection of Salmonella in processing facilities. The sensor-chip was first integrated to the tube cap, which was then connected using a USB port to a portable potentiostat for bacteria detection. The resulting electrochemical sensor exhibited a limit of detection of 13 CFU/10 mL and 17-minute response time with a wide Salmonella Typhimurium linear sensing range in chicken broth, covering relevant concentration levels for food safety analysis. We were able to reach our project milestone for commercialization feasibility upon the detection of Salmonella (25-mL sample, less than 20 min) with a limit of detection = 5 CFU/mL, which is the required level by regulatory agencies.

 

This project resulted in a rapid and robust platform technology for effective monitoring of Salmonella in complex matrices, such as food samples and in the presence of interferent.  The ability to eliminate bacterial enrichment, while still sensitively and selectively detecting Salmonella species within 20 min satisfies the value demanded by the market by food-processing professionals: improved sensitivity, ability to test in a variety of matrices, and a rapid test with much faster results.

 

Currently, technologies for foodborne pathogen sensing rely primarily on sample enrichment (~22 to 24 hours), which can often be followed by a secondary enrichment step (another ~22 to 24 hours). This rapid analysis is expected to provide a significant economic advantage over current state-of-the-art techniques by reducing response times for laboratory testing and allowing processing plants to optimize intervention strategies onsite in real time. The resulting technology is capable to detect foodborne pathogens before food processors ship to consumers, and to assist in the development of effective measures for foodborne pathogen control in food processing facilities. Consequently, it has a broad positive impact in reducing the economic burden of recalls and foodborne diseases and ensuring a safe food supply by reducing threats to human health and assisting with reducing food waste.
